description.narrative: The Project contributes to reducing rural poverty in very poor/remote hill and mountain regions in 18 districts of Nepal, by widening access to social services/economic opportunities. It will bring economic benefits among people by improving their access to markets and services. It will reduce poverty by generating 4.7 million person days of off-farm employment, of which 50% goes to disadvantaged groups (DAGs) and directly benefiting 0.9 million through road access in the Zone of Influence (ZoI). It will ensure increased participation of DAGs and women. Since the DRILP project started in 2005, over 455 km of roads constructed and rehabilitated. Key outputs from 2012-2015: (1) 260 km of rural roads are built (200 km new construction and 60 km upgraded); 1200 km of roads maintained; Around 200 other small community infrastructures will be built/rehabilitated; 4.7 mio person days of employment created at local level; 60% of them are from DAGs. (2) Capacity of 18 District Development Committees (DDCs) strengthened in planning, implementation and management of local infrastructure projects; 40% women and DAGs are represented and able to influence decisions in building groups; Skills of 3000 people (40% of which are women and 60% are DAGs) enhanced. - Overall goal: The programme’s goal is to contribute towards poverty reduction through enhanced mobility of isolated rural people. This will have an impact on overall local economic development through improved access to goods and social services and economic opportunities in 18 very poor and remote hill and mountain districts of Nepal.
